definition:
Any metric $d: X \times X \to \mathbb{R}$ on a set $X$ must satisfy the
triangle inequality:

$$(\forall x,y,z) \quad d(x,z) \leq d(x,y) + d(y,z)$$

An [*ultrametric*]{} must additionally satisfy a stronger version of the
triangle inequality:

$$(\forall x,y,z) \quad d(x,z) \leq \max\{ d(x,y),  d(y,z) \}$$

Here is an example of an ultrametric on a space with 5 points, labelled
$a,b,c,d,e$:

$$\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c|c}
   & a  & b  & c  & d  & e
\\ \hline
 a & 0  & 12 & 4  & 6  & 12
\\ \hline
 b &    & 0  & 12 & 12 & 5
\\ \hline
 c &    &    & 0  & 6  & 12
\\ \hline
 d &    &    &    & 0  & 12
\\ \hline
 e &    &    &    &    & 0
\end{array}$$

In the table above, an entry $n$ in the for element $x$ and the for
element $y$ indicates that $d(x,y)=n$, where $d$ is the ultrametric. By
symmetry of the ultrametric ($d(x,y)=d(y,x)$), the above table yields
all values of $d(x,y)$ for all $x,y \in \{a,b,c,d,e\}$.

The ultrametric condition is equivalent to the ultrametric three point
condition:

$$(\forall x,y,z) \quad x,y,z \textrm{ can be renamed such that } d(x,z) \leq d(x,y) = d(y,z)$$

Ultrametrics can be used to model bifurcating hierarchical systems. The
distance between nodes in a weight-balanced binary tree is an
ultrametric. Similarly, an ultrametric can be modelled by a
weight-balanced binary tree, although the choice of tree is not
necessarily unique. Tree models of ultrametrics are sometimes called
*ultrametric trees*.

The metrics induced by non-Archimedean valuations are ultrametrics.
